bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby and Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 18, 1941

div1.p: Hench wonders if Agramonte was with Lazear at his death because Carroll claimed that Agramonte had left three days earlier.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby and Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 18, 1941
div1.opener:
March 18, 1941
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.
Georgetown, Washington, D. C.
Dear Generals Truby and Kean:
div1.p:
I am leaving Friday for Florida and Havana. I certainly appreciate all
you have done to help me. I am sending you either by separate post or by express
depending on the relative expense, a note book containing photostatic articles by
Hemmeter and Donnally regarding Maj. Carroll. I have marked these articles with
my notes and would appreciate it if you would read them at your leisure and with
ink or pencil write your own comments either on the margin or on the back of the
pages. I will consider them confidential. I am very anxious to have your reaction
to them and I do not believe you have seen them. Note especially the letter to
MajMrs. Carroll in which he states that Dr. and Mrs. Agramonte left Havana two or
three days before Lazear's death and in view of what Dr. Argramonte wrote this
idea seems impossible and yet there it is. I have a letter which Dr. Agramonte
wrote to Mrs. Lazear sometime after Dr. Lazear's death in which she mourned the
latter's death and made some remark to the effect that he would never forget the
day Dr. Lazear died. I asked Mrs. Lazear about this and she felt that Maj. Carroll
surely must have been in error. She had been lead to believe that Dr. Agramonte
was with Dr. Lazear when he died and felt sure that since Reed was also away and
Major Carroll was still here, Dr. Argramonte most assuredly could not have left.

I will send this notation first to General Truby and ask you (Gen. Truby)
to send it to General Kean. I am doing this because General Keen has just written
that he has been none too well recently. There is no particular hurry about returning
it until I return to Rochester, about April 26th.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Philip S. Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
PSH:FP
P. S. I have long since received my little tin box but you did not return the key.
As I had an extra key it made no particular difference but I wonder if you happen to
have the key and would return it to me, if not it will be an easy matter to have an
extra key made. I will return to Rochester about the 26th of April for only a week
when I go to Atlantic City for the medical meetings May 5th to 7th. I hope to return
through Washington, D. C. and perhaps spend the 8th or 9th of May in Washington. You
have often expressed yourwillingness to discuss matters at length if only we could
General Kean
-2-
March 18, 1941
do it face to face and without the need for long hand writing on your part. Would
you be willing to try and arrange to have a professional stenographer spend the
afternoon or as much time as will be required while you and I visit with each other.
I could ask you many questions and you could give me much information which she
could transcribe and give you a copy for correction and approval before letting me
have it finally. I shall be delighted to pay her expenses. If you know of a
stenographer whom you would prefer, it would be splendid, otherwise, I think I
could get help from one of my medical friends whose secretary might be available
and willing to earn a little extra money.
P. S. Hench, M. D.
My addresses
Hotel Villa Atlantique - Palm Beach Fla Mar 23 - April 16
except for 1 week in Havana - Hotel Nacional Mar 28 - Apr 3.
Hotel Statler, Boston Mass Apr 20-25.
Home thereafter till May 3 → to Atlantic City & return
via Washington.
